basics.name: Jonathan Z. Ong
basics.label: Research Assistant
basics.summary: Research assistant working on infant social cognition and early risk screening, modeling parent–infant synchrony across behavior (video/annotations), brain (EEG), and physiology (ECG). Builds play-based, naturalistic tasks; develops end-to-end pipelines that derive novel social interaction metrics; and constructs large multimodal datasets for predictive modeling and clinical translation. Experience spans optogenetic rodent models, dynamical systems approaches, and cross-disciplinary collaboration.

work.name: Nanyang Technological University, Singapore
work.summary: Developing an end-to-end pipeline integrating multimodal parent–infant play data (EEG, ECG, video, behavioral annotations) to derive novel social interaction metrics and train predictive models for early neurodevelopmental risk.
highlights: Curate one of the largest datasets of its kind to train predictive models of infant neurodevelopmental profiles from as early as 12 months.
Advance clinical translation by designing novel social interaction metrics with applications in both diagnostic and commercial settings.

work.name: Sunway University
work.summary: AGEWELL project on cognitive aging in a socioeconomically diverse Malaysian cohort.
highlights: Recruited and assessed older adults (60+) with neuropsychological testing and EEG.
Derived event-related potentials as neural markers of executive function and aging-related decline.
Examined the protective role of cognitive reserve against age-related cognitive decline.

work.name: Monash University Malaysia
work.summary: Supported social- and cultural-psychology projects on stigma, dyadic interaction, and indigenous psychology.
highlights: Conducted literature reviews and qualitative analyses (transcription, Malay-to-English translation, thematic coding) on cancer stigma.
Applied the Actor–Partner Interdependence Model (APIM) to dyadic social-interaction data.
Co-organized the Southeast Asian Indigenous Psychology Scientific Meetings (2021, 2022).

publications.name: Helicopter parenting and social competence among single Malaysian adults: Filial piety as a moderator
publications.summary: Among single Malaysian adults, perceived childhood helicopter parenting related to lower competence in relationship initiation only for those lower in reciprocal filial piety, with no associations for other social-competence domains.

publications.name: Protocol to study dam–pup social transmission using a modified paradigm for transmission of food preference
publications.summary: Presents an optogenetic-compatible protocol to investigate neural mechanisms of social learning in mouse dam–pup dyads.

publications.name: It’s a guy thing: Sex as a moderator of the relationship between social anxiety and perception of interpersonal warmth in initial heterosexual interactions
publications.summary: In initial opposite-sex interactions, higher social anxiety predicted perceiving less partner warmth among men but not among women.

projects.name: Sociometric AI Screening Tool to Risk-Stratify Infant Neurodevelopmental Trajectories
projects.summary: Developing an early-screening framework from naturalistic parent–child interactions with children aged 6–36 months to identify neurodevelopmental risk.
highlights: Developed play-based tasks indexing working memory, inhibition, and cognitive flexibility in naturalistic parent–child contexts.
Linked social contingency and EEG/ECG synchrony to emerging executive functions.
Validated social interaction metrics against clinician ratings and standardized developmental screens for clinical translation.

projects.name: Optogenetic Parent–Offspring Mouse Model of Neural Synchrony and Social Learning
projects.summary: Integrated behavioral assays with optogenetics to test the causal role of prefrontal neural synchrony in naturalistic parent–offspring social learning
highlights: Applied recurrence quantification analysis to dam–pup interactions and foraging behavior.
In vivo optogenetic manipulation; immunohistochemical verification of medial prefrontal targeting.
Maintained and validated transgenic lines (e.g., PV-Cre/ChR2).
